title: Raikkonen not Finnish-ed yet
text:
NASCAR'S Gordon chasing sixth title at Brickyard 
Kimi Raikkonen hasn't won for Ferrari in 2015 and has only two podium finishes in the first 14 Grand Prix races, but that doesn't mean he hasn't been an important part of the Scuderia revival this season. 
The 35-year-old native of Finland has nine top-five results, which have contributed mightily to the all-important constructor points total that Ferrari has earned so far. 
There was a point early this year at Monza, however, when rumours had Raikkonen being jettisoned from the team in favour of a younger driver. 
Those rumours were aided and abetted by Raikkonen himself saying he wasn't happy being second banana behind teammate Sebastian Vettel . 
Since then, however, Raikkonen has third- and fourth-place finishes at Marina Bay and Suzuka, respectively. 
It was this kind of form that made it easy for Ferrari boss Maurizio Arrivabene to sign the Finn to an extension of his contract through to the end of the 2016 season. 
On Saturday, Raikkonen qualified his No. 7 Ferrari fifth on a lap of 1:38.348, just a tick off Vettel's time. 
The man who earned the nickname "the Iceman" still feels he has the skills and the determination to get to the top step of the podium in the world's top open-wheel series. 
"Hopefully we can win, but that's the aim always," he said. "If it happens this year then it happens, if not we try next year again but obviously the aim is to be first." 
TO 10 THINGS TO WATCH FOR AT THE RUSSIAN GRAND PRIX 
ALSO RAN: Once again, two-time world champion Fernando Alonso will be starting from the back of the gird in his McLaren Honda. It is painful to watch such a talent struggle with an uncompetitive race car. 
KID IS ALRIGHT: Twenty-one-year-old Carlos Sainz suffered only minor injuries after a big crash in practice Saturday and it will be a race-time decision on whether he will get back in the Toro Rosso team car on Sunday. 
SPARKS FLY: A bumpy temporary street circuit at Sochi combined with full fuel loads will result in plenty of fireworks as the F-1 cars bottom out around the 19-turn, 5.848 km track. 
PRACTICE WOES: It will be interesting to see how the rain- and crash-shortened practices on Friday and Saturday affect the race strategy on Sunday. Certainly, tire management issues won't be a factor with so few practice laps. 
HOME BOY: Russian driver Daniil Kvyat will have plenty of fans around the Sochi circuit cheering on his No. 26 Toro Rosso machine. He will need all the help he can get after missing the final round of qualifying. 
RED BULLISH: With rumours swirling around the paddock that Red Bull is on the brink of pulling out of F-1, it will be fun to follow the soap opera in Sochi as attempts are being made to find a new engine provider for the Austrian team. 
BACK MARKERS: Besides Alonso, the back of the grid will have its usual inhabitants -- Will Stevens and Roberto Merhi -- in the Marussia/Ferraris. No reason to believe they will finish any higher than their starting positions. 
THE CHAMP: Reigning world champion Lewis Hamilton will start second on Sunday in Sochi behind Mercedes teammate Nico Rosberg, but that has never been much of an impediment for Hamilton. 
PICTURE PERFECT: Although it was cold and breezy for Saturday qualifying in the Russian Olympic city, forecsast for Sunday is for mostly sunny skies and temperatures near 20C -- making for perfect racing conditions. 
SITTING PRETTY: Roseberg has been there before -- on the front row ahead of Hamilton -- and it hasn't worked out. He will need to out race his teammate through the first lap if he has any chance of winning at Sochi. 
MY PICK 
Nico Rosberg should be getting tired of getting his seat handed to him by Mercedes teammate Lewis Hamilton. 
It seems like every time Rosberg bests Hamilton on qualifying, the reigning champion finds a way to get past him on the first lap, often in the first turn, 
Rosberg has been stung by criticism that he can't keep pace with Hamilton and he has to prove that theory wrong if he wants to break out of the two time champion's shadow. 
I think that will be motivation enough to push him to beat Hamilton on Sunday in Sochi at the Russian Grand Prix. 
Rosberg likely can't catch Hamilton for the championship this season but a win at Sochi will at least keep him close. 
THE BLIND SPOT 
Romain Grosjean has only one top five finish this Formula 1 season in the No. 8 Lotus Mercedes but his potential has been seen as impressive enough to earn a job next year in the inaugural Haas F-1 car. On Saturday he posted a lap of 1:38.787 for an eighth place spot on the grid for the Russian Grand Prix. A trouble free day could see him surprise. Sponsored Links
